taxpayer, but didn't originally, sorry, you can only have 50 cents on the dollar.

You're kind of bubbled up, as we say, most of the time.

If you cover Congress you move around the Capitol a lot and through the various House offices.

But at the White House, you're kind of penned up in that White House briefing room, and you spend a lot of time trying to email and call White House aides to try to find out what's going on, and that's a pretty arduous task.
So it's kind of a bubbled-up world, and obviously, you travel with the president, you know, almost all of over the globe, and so you're kind of a part of this traveling show, if you will.
So it's an interesting life, but a pretty unique one journalistically.
And it kind of - in some ways can be limiting journalistically, too, if you're not careful.
I got to go on Air Force One a couple of times as part of the press pool, which is not the same as the press corps.
You just, you kind of rotate on - but the question is more, for the people who are part of the press corps, is there a lot of color in the room?
Is there a lot of diversity?
And does it make a difference?

I mean, I know that you have a perspective from being in that position, but do you think, as much as you can tell us, that it makes a difference whether or not you have people of color who are part of the White House press corps?

You know, I was struck by how few African-Americans, and really, other minorities were in the press corps when I did it under Bush.
And really, I mean, that's actually a charge you could probably apply to the business generally.
It seems like diversity is - it's slipping.
I don't know that latest numbers, but it just doesn't feel like it's expanding, despite all the talk about it.
And I think it matters when it comes down to stories, kind of our filters.

Not that every black or minority reporter will filter stories the same way, but I think we have different, you know, different sensibilities and so on that would elevate some things into the level of, you know, being a story while maybe, you know, pushing other things aside.
I think we'd bring different contexts to stories.
So I think it's important to have diversity, and not just racially, but you know, gender and, you know, and sort of the whole panoply of the kinds of diversities you can think of.
I think it really does impact coverage.

Enjoy, but be in good taste.

And folks found out, wow, surprise, these guys actually can be reporters.
And they weren't necessarily formally trained in any way, but they also hadn't been given the opportunity.

At the same time, you want to think as a reporter that you can learn so that you don't have to be of one race to be able to cover a certain topic.
How do you make sense of the question of lived experience as well as learned experience when you go out on the road, Michael?
That's an interesting question.
One thing I do know is you talk about the kind of the first generation of sort of the big wave of African-American reporters coming in.

I look back, it's interesting, striking, to look back at newspaper coverage, you know, from 30 or 40 years ago, particularly when the black community is being written about, and just the distance that you can sense in the stories.
Like, you know, where writing is almost like, you know, we were venturing to a foreign land to write about these people.
And I think there's sort of that lived experience that closes that gap.
You know, we write with, you know, with more familiarity.
We write like, you know, this is part of our society, you know.
So I think it just sets a different tone for the coverage.

So let me just add to this, when you have a black family - and as Richard pointed out, it really will be a family and not just one person - in the White House, is there a value to having at least some people who have lived experience of being black?
Yeah.
I would like to think so.
I think of course.
I mean, I think there are just so many things you kind of get instantly that, you know, that wouldn't be maybe obvious to someone who doesn't have that same, as you put it, lived experience.
So I think it's important.
Again, it's not to say that if Richard and I are covering, you know, the White House we're going to write the exact same stories and our stories will, you know, always agree.
But at the same time, I think there's a certain kind of, again, sort of cultural kind of understanding that, you know, you sort of have just intuitively.
Richard, what's the path ahead for news organizations dealing with their needs to cover a time of immense change in America, including changes in how we perceive race and leadership?

What's - why is it important?
Because your audience is becoming more diverse, and you want to be able to relate to those members of your audience, of your readership or your listenership.
Indian Americans, for example, are voracious newspaper readers.
And so it makes sense if you're a newspaper and you've got an Indian American community to try to cater to that audience so they'll keep buying your paper.

We saw the evidence of the hunger of African-Americans for great news about the progress of black people in this country last week, when all the newspapers were snapped up announcing Barack Obama's election, and 65 percent or so of those people were African-Americans themselves, who wanted to make sure that - to preserve that bit of history for their children and grandchildren.

So the future of the business is in catering to the changing demographics in your own market, and there's - even though there's been a contraction in the general interest newspapers, we find that ethnic newspapers and broadcast outlets are just - you know, Hispanic publications and weekly newspapers that cater to certain ethnic groups are actually growing.
All right.

Kim Thuy's new novel unfolds in the way a flower casts off petals - one small scene after another.
Ru"" is an autobiographical novel in which memories are shuffled back and forth to tell the story of a 10-year-old who...well, let Kim Thuy introduce herself.

(Reading) I came into the world during the Tet Offensive in the early days of the Year of the Monkey, when the long chains of firecrackers draped in front of houses exploded, polyphonically, along with the sound of machine guns.

I first saw the light of day in Saigon, where firecrackers fragmented into a thousand shreds, colored the ground red, like the petals of cherry blossoms, or like the blood of the two million soldiers deployed and scattered throughout the villages and cities of a Vietnam that had been ripped in two.
I was born in the shadow of skies, adorned with fireworks, decorated with garlands of light shot through with rockets and missiles.
The purpose of my birth was to replace life that had been lost.
Like her story's narrator, Kim Thuy and her family fled South Vietnam in boats.

Tossed and scattered across the world, they took shelter and struggled to survive in refugee camps, finally winding up in the suburbs of Montreal, where she picked vegetables after school and sewed clothes with other refugees.
She became an interpreter, then a lawyer and a restaurateur.
Ru"" won Canada's Governor General's Award and has been published in 20 countries around the world, and now here in the United States, translated by Sheila Fischman.
Kim Thuy joins us from the studios of the CBC in Montreal.
Thank you so much for being with us.
Thank you so much for inviting me.
And you describe your autobiographical character as being part of that group we call boat people, but I gather you're eager for people to know that many families had it worse than yours did.
Absolutely, absolutely.
We were very, very lucky because we spent only four nights at sea and only four months in a camp, whereas just recently I've met one Vietnamese who was in a camp in the Philippines for 12 years.
So, we were very lucky.
Can you help us understand what it's like for parents, for grandparents to load their children into a boat not knowing where in the world it will wind up really, or if it will land safely at all?
I was lucky that I was young.
I was only 10.
I understood some bits then, but most of it I was not conscious of the weight of the whole decision.
But now that I'm older than my parents when they left, I still wonder how you can make this kind of decision.

But I guess the pressure that we had in Vietnam was big enough for them to take this chance or take this risk, I would say, not chance, because we really thought it was not 50-50 that we would survive or die.
It was, I don't know, I think we expected to die more than to survive.
What's it like to come from war, this perilous boat trip and a refugee camp, to the nice, soft pillowy snows of Quebec?
Oh, it was a new birth really.
And that purity.
You know, when you come from a country at war, again, with men in uniforms and curfews and - we didn't see blood as such, but still it was on our mind.
That was the background of Vietnam.
And then afterwards, we were in the refugee camp in Malaysia and we were surrounded by dirt basically and I was going to say the septic tank.

You know, from the plane, that's what we saw.
And that purity really changed us all, gave us a second birth.
Can you recollect for me, as you describe in the book, the conversations that you and other young Vietnamese women had while sewing clothes?
Yeah.
Well, you know, when we first arrived here, of course, we were very poor and we had to do many jobs.
